literally\u003cbr\u003e\nJoin them together into one wire and then insert that wire into the \u003cspan class=\"abbreviation\"\u003eVRM\u003ctemplate class=\"tooltiptext\" data-text=\"Voltage Regulator Module\"\u003e\u003c/template\u003e\u003c/span\u003e. Make sure the current that both devices demand can be supplied by the \u003cspan class=\"abbreviation\"\u003eVRM\u003ctemplate class=\"tooltiptext\" data-text=\"Voltage Regulator Module\"\u003e\u003c/template\u003e\u003c/span\u003e, and that the wire gauges are in spec as Hub\"\u003e\u003c/template\u003e\u003c/span\u003e.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eExcept for R616A (powering the radio from the \u003cspan class=\"abbreviation\"\u003eVRM\u003ctemplate class=\"tooltiptext\" data-text=\"Voltage Regulator Module\"\u003e\u003c/template\u003e\u003c/span\u003e, for which the splice to another device is not allowed), the \u003cspan class=\"abbreviation\"\u003eVRM\u003ctemplate class=\"tooltiptext\" data-text=\"Voltage Regulator Module\"\u003e\u003c/template\u003e\u003c/span\u003e does not appear to have such a rule, but itâ€™s a good idea anyway as the connectors are made for a single wire, and if one of the two falls out, it may be a lot more difficult to find the issue than if the only one falls
